stories.title: Fix the unit test and open a giant hole everywhere

stories.text:
When I search a word or phrase in Google Chrome's default Bookmarks Manager, I get a bunch of search results, but no indication in the same UI (e.g. via breadcrumbs) of the folder path hierarchical structure that each returned result may be nested inside.

(To get some inkling of what folder a returned result is in: I need to select a returned result, right-click, and then choose "Show in Folder"... this is a very slow and tedious process.)

The folder path hierarchical structure is very important to me because it's meta data that indicates the relevance of each returned result.

The closest thing that does this that I've found so far is a Chrome Extension called "TabIt - BookMarks: Productivity in Access". I found it after a long search of Extensions on the Chrome Web Store, using a bunch of potentially relevant keywords, etc. I didn't find anything else (there were two others that were almost useful, but they used "fuzzy search" that returned irrelevant results).

If you've found anything else that indicates each returned result's location in the folder hierarchy (e.g. via breadcrumbs) after doing a bookmarks search, please share. Thanks.
stories.title: Ask HN: Chrome bookmarks search results with folder path hierarchy breadcrumbs?

stories.text: Why are there 1000s of public snapshots and AMI images in AWS? Are these possibly snapshots that weren't meant to be public due to misconfiguration? Most have no description whatsoever and anyone can just use.
stories.title: Ask HN: What are public AWS snapshots?
